25154892.review:
Если интерактивная литература и существует, то «Книга ненаписанных историй» занимает сейчас в её ряду одно из первых мест.

Говорят жанр «point-and-click» квеста мёртв. Как никак третье тысячелетие уже. К счастью это не так. Квест не только выжил, но и обзавёлся красивой графикой, правда обитает он теперь не в дочерних подразделениях ведущих издателей, а среди независимых разработчиков. Компания KING Art^Games из немецкого Бремена — пример такой мастерской грёз.

Организованная в 2000 году студия выстрелила в 2009 году сказкой The Book of Unwritten Tales с традиционной механикой «point-and-click». Это сказка, в которой нельзя умереть, да и вообще сделать что-то не так. Это красивое приключение, проходить которое несложно и любопытно. 

Повествование не лишено дыр в сюжете, но держит игрока в тонусе в меру внезапными поворотами. Простой и незатейливый гремлин-археолог, имеющий традиционные шляпу и кнут, обнаружил в книге информацию о супер артефакте. Этим фактом заинтересовалось Зло, ведущее войну с переменным успехом против Добра. В момент, когда гремлина выволакивали из его дома, в казалось бы успешную операцию злобных сил вмешалась эльфийская принцесса. Дальше всё пошло кувырком. Поэтому гном получил кольцо и наставление найти архимага.

Особую прелесть этого произведения представляет букет многочисленных заимствований, постоянно циркулирующих в современном обществе мемов. Поданные в обёртке иронии они оставляют незабываемую послевкусицу узнавания. Такой подход принято описывать как постмодернизм.  Вас ждут встречи с узнаваемыми персонажами и воззрениями. Особого внимания заслуживают главные герои истории, которые, естественно, в конце концов спасают мир. Вот они: 

* Иво — настоящая принцесса эльфов. Просто гуляла по лесу и увидела ездового дракона тёмных сил. Не очень высокого мнения о людях в целом. Из рогатки способна оглушить тролля.

* Уилбур — молодой гном, который не очень любит традиционную для гномов стезю механиков и инженеров. Хочет стать магом. До смерти боится заходить в комнату своей младшей сестры, которая специализируется на конструировании роботов-убийц.

* Нэйт — человек, постоянно утверждающий что он законченный эгоист. Пытается убедить себя в этом, но время от времени ему приходится спасть мир совершенно бесплатно, отчего и страдает. В приквеле предсказал, что встретит принцессу эльфов.

* Существо (Critter) — пурпурный инопланетянин. Среди своих мудрых и ответственных соотечественников, считается никчёмным, «без царя в голове». К счастью не все соотечественники ответственные. Так и не выучил язык туземцев. Привязался к Нэйту.

В 2012 год был выпущен приквел The Book of Unwritten Tale: The Critter Chronicles, в котором рассказывалось откуда появилось Существо и почему он связался с Нэйтом. В приквеле была значительно улучшена графическая составляющая и почти изничтожена проблема «охоты за пикселями» или поиска активных зон (теперь они подсвечиваются по требованию).  В приквеле не осталось места Иво и Уилбору. Сценарий стал гораздо более связанным, но резко уменьшилось число сцен и время неспешного прохождения с 19 часов сократилось до 8. Зато там есть пингвины, которые почему-то живут на севере. Северные пингвины весьма брутальны, хоть и не распространяются об этом факте.

В ноябре 2012 года, почти сразу после запуска бета—версии Steam для GNU/Linux, на нём объявились Linux-порты обеих историй. KING Arts Games довольно последовательно поддерживает пока ещё не самую популярную среди игроделов нашу основную платформу. В частности поддержка гарантирована для активно разрабатываемой пошаговой стратегии «Battle Worlds: Kronos», часть ресурсов для которой была собрана у сообщества через Kickstarter.

При запуске игра может не распознать родное разрешение монитора. В этом случае правильное разрешение следует выбрать в настройках и перезапустить игру. При выходе из полноэкранного режима могут быть проблемы со сменой разрешения. В остальном игра работала безукоризненно.

В России издателем первой части выступил 1С-СофтКлаб, которые выпустили локализованную версию весной 2012 года. Про версию под GNU/Linux ничего не известно, поэтому русскоязычным пользователям Linux приходится смириться копией игры полученной через Steam с английской озвучкой и субтитрами. Хотя, разные источники сообщают, что в принципе можно «накатить» русификатор. С другой стороны те же источники говорят, что для восприятия историй лучше выучить английский.

[h1]Этот обзор входит в список [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1103944566]Игры, Linux, Steam, обзоры[/url].[/h1]

25153113.review:
[h1]Absolutes Topspiel, selten so viel Freude gehabt :) ![/h1] 

Das Spiel ist gespickt mit herrlichen Anspielungen auf die bekannten Figuren und Szenen des Fantasy-Genres und die Spielkultur im allgemeinen, weshalb ich ca. alle zwei Minuten in lautes Lachen ausgebrochen bin. Auch die Story an sich kann man als Parodie auffassen, die zunächst alle klassischen Elemente einer Fantasygeschichte aufgreift und jedes Klischee bedient (selbstredend immer wieder süffisant kommentiert), zum Schluss aber durchaus noch eine überraschende Wendung parat hat. Man spielt verschiedene liebenswert-schrullige Charaktere, die auch hervorragend vertont sind (Wilbur z.B. von Oliver Rohrbeck, die älteren unter uns kennen ihn als Justus Jonas von den Drei Fragezeichen!). 

Die Rätsel und zu bewältigenden Aufgaben sind logisch aufgebaut und nicht zu schwer, dazu gibt es auch noch eine Ingame-Hilfefunktion (Space-Taste), die bei Bedarf die Hotspots anzeigt. Apropos Hotspots: Ich habe es als sehr angenehm empfunden, dass die Interaktionspunkte inaktiviert werden, sobald sie keinen Nutzen mehr haben. Das erspart eine Menge sinnloses Rumgeklicke. 

Die grundlegende Spielmechanik besteht aus meist zweistufigen Dialogen (mit NPCs oder zeitweise auch anderen spielbaren Charakteren, zwischen denen man hin und her switchen kann) und dem Sammeln und Kombinieren von Gegenständen. Dabei beeinflusst der Spielfortschritt die Dialoge, so dass es oft sinnvoll ist, nochmal an einen früheren Ort zurückzukehren. Bald wird man auch merken, dass bei mehreren Gesprächsoptionen fast immer die letzte auch die "zielführende" ist - aber wer sich den Spaß entgehen lässt, die anderen auszuprobieren, ist selbst schuld ;). Daneben gibt es noch einige Spielelemente, die wie Mini-Games gestaltet sind. Das Brauen eines Trankes erfordert z.B., dass die Zutaten in der richtigen Reihenfolge und zum richtigen Zeitpunkt zugegeben werden und dann (mit der Maus) soundso oft im oder gegen den Uhrzeigersinn umgerührt werden, sonst explodiert der Topf und man darf von vorne beginnen. Dieses Element fand ich sehr faszinierend und hatte ich so vorher noch nicht gesehen. Leider hat mein [b]einziger großer Kritikpunkt[/b] auch mit diesen Minispielen zu tun. Eines davon [spoiler]- der Regentanz -[/spoiler] forderte Reaktionsschnelligkeit und Hand-Auge-Koordination und schien mir unverhältnismäßig hart zu sein. Ich konnte es nicht selbst bewältigen, aber auch nicht auslassen, da es für den Spielfortschritt entscheidend war und musste es "fremdspielen" lassen, das war schon sehr frustrierend. Allerdings bin ich auch schon ein älteres Semester und in dem Bereich noch nie sehr begabt gewesen ;). Ansonsten hat das Spiel ein paar kleine Macken, die einen aber wirklich nicht abhalten sollten:
[list]
[*]Animationen manchmal etwas langatmig und nicht abschaltbar
[*]Grafik ist nicht mehr ganz neu und ausgerechnet in der Anfangsszene besonders grobschlächtig. Wird aber dann besser.
[*]Untertitel haben einige Rechtschreibfehler und weichen teils von der Sprachausgabe ab
[*]Ein aktiver Support scheint nicht mehr zu existieren (war für mich aber auch nicht erforderlich, da keine technischen Probleme aufgetreten sind und inhaltliche Fragen sich gut googeln oder per Guide aufklären lassen)
[/list]

[b]Fazit:[/b]

Mein neues Lieblingsspiel, dem ich kleine Mängel locker verzeihe. Pflichtkauf für alle Fantasy-Fans und Spieleveteranen und überhaupt Leute, die in letzter Zeit zu wenig Spaß hatten. Vielleicht eher nichts für ungeduldige 13-Jährige, aber für die gibt es ja die MMORPGs ;)

Gráficos, Música, diseño de personajes, entornos, todo en general muy bien encajado.

24515685.review:
Un Point & Click sympatique. Le GamePlay est classique et bien pensé, les enigmes sont quant à elles relativement simples car plutôt "logiques" (pour des joueurs habitués aux combinaisons farfelues). L'univers est agréable et constamment humoristique, vous y trouverez un nombre incalculable de références...

Le jeu est en VOSTF mais franchement même comme celà on y prend beaucoup de plaisir, en effet les voix en Anglais sont vraiment bien réussies (quelques traductions de textes étanges et des phrases en Allemand mais bon globalement ça ne gêne pas trop). La bande musicale est variée et très agréable.

Les graphismes sont beau surtout au niveau des décors, certains visages le sont un peu moins.

L'histoire n'est certe pas originale mais amusante et l'on a pas trop d'aller-retour à faire pour résoudre chaque situation, les objets disparaissant généralement lorsqu'ils ne sont plus utiles rend le jeu beaucoup plus simple. Les développeurs ont véritablement essayés de créer de la profondeur aussi bien pour les personnages que pour la progression de l'histoire, on progresse donc petit à petit en alternant les personnages.

Sans doute un peu trop facile, la variétée (les personnages, les situations, les quelques rares mini-jeux, les aires de jeu, les angles de vues...), l'ambiance générale et la très bonne durée de jeu (l'aventure se déroule sur 5 chapitres faisables en une quinzaine d'heures sans trop être bloqué) font que je le conseille vraiment pour tous les amateurs du genre.

24426127.review:
Hab dieses Spiel echt verschlungen. Es ist der Hammer.

Diese liebe zum Detail im Level Design, die Charaktere, die Anspielungen zu anderen Spielen, Genres und Filmen sind einfach der Wahnsinn, auch die Raetsel sind echt gut gelungen. Beim Raetsel loesen hatte ich auch nie das Gefuehl hoffnungslos verloren gewesen zu sein, es gibt immer einen Hinweis der den Groschen Fallen laesst.
 
Bei manchen Spielen ist es bei mir so, dass ich keinen Bock auf die vollstaendigen Dialoge habe, bei dem hier aber sind die Dialoge so genial und lustig, dass du freiwillig alle Dialogoptionen ausprobierst nur um dir den Arsch ablachen zu koennen.

Einziger Negativpunkt den ich habe ist, dass das Spiel etwas kurz war (gefuehlt) und das Ende doch recht abrupt kam (Das kann aber auch eine Besonderheit des Genres sein, ich hab vorher ehrlich gesagt noch keine P&C-Adventure gespielt ... ^^). Was mich sehr sehr traurig gemacht hat. (hab es bisher aber auch nur im Normalen Schwierigskeitsgrad gespielt, bei Schwer koennte man ggf. laengere Spielzeit haben) 

Wenn ihr das Game im Angebot seht kann ich es nur emfehlen, an sich wuerde ich persoenlich auch den Vollpreis als gutes Preis/Leistungsverhaeltnis bezeichnen.

Hab mit den Critter Chronicles grad angefangen und ich denke, dass Critter Chronicles der eigentliche Erste Teil ist, und dieser hier der Zweite. Jedenfalls kam es mir im Einfuehrungskapitel so vor.

Soweit erstmal von mir, Gl Hf und Game hard, Freunde! :D

This is cute, light, and funny.

23830328.review:
Nur wenige Point'n'Click-Adventures schaffen es aus dem Schatten der Lucasarts-Adventures, allem voran Day of the Tentacle oder Monkey Island, hervorzutreten. The Book of Unwritten Tales ist eines davon und es legt die Messlatte wieder erstaunlich hoch. 

Es ist definitiv das Lustigste, das ich seit langem spielen durfte. Unzählige Querverweise und Zitate auf andere Spiele, Filme, Serien und die Nerdkultur bringen einen immer wieder zum Schmunzeln. Durch die stringente Geschichte ziehen sich Gags und Witze ohne aufgesetzt und lächerlich zu wirken. Stellenweise nimmt es sich selbst nicht so ernst und das macht TBOUT unglaublich sympathisch. Die Möglichkeit mit drei unterschiedlichen Charakteren zu spielen, macht es zudem extrem kurzweilig. 

Dazu kommt, dass Grafik, Perspektivwechsel und Szenerie unglaublich abwechslungreich und verpielt detailliert sind. Die zudem noch großartige Musik untermalt das alles perfekt. 
Das Sahnehäubchen sind aber die hochkarätigen Synchronsprecher, die man aus bekannten Hörspielen oder gar Filmen kennt. Auch hier kommt man immer wieder ins Grübeln, woher man diese Stimme wohl kennt. (Na? Wer hat Justus Jonas aus den Drei ??? erkannt?)

Bei all dem Lob fällt es schwer etwas Negatives zu finden. Gibt es auch nicht. Sicher könnte man sich beklagen, dass die Rätsel gerade für Adventure-Profis oft zu leicht sind oder dass dagegen pixelgenaue Objekte oft nur durch Zufall entdeckt werden, aber das ist Jammern auf hohem Niveau.

Alles in allem hat es einen hohen Wiederspielwert, weil man viele Gags und Szenen gerne wiedersehen möchte.

Meine persönliche Wertung: eine glatte 9 von 10. Absolutes MUST PLAY.

23526832.review:
As someone who’s not normally a fan of point-and-click adventure games I wasn’t particularly excited when I sat down to play The Book of Unwritten Tales - but I got it on sale so I thought “what the heck.” I have to say I was pleasantly surprised. While the game follows the general rules of point-and-click adventures - you go from room to room picking up various objects and figuring out how they interact with each other and the enviroment -  what really sells the game is the humor. 

I find that it’s really hard to make games funny, but The Book of Unwritten Tales succeeds. The key is that the game just doesn’t take itself overly seriously. and the writers feel free to poke fun at it, and wider gaming topics, at will. In addition, the game makes you the think, but none of the puzzles feel unfair. You just have to be willing to spend some time poking around a bit and trying out different things. The whole game only takes about twenty hours to complete.

There are certain points where I found particularly small items a little bit harder to find that I felt was fair - and the game doesn’t explain that you can right-click your items to find out more about them - but those are really my only complaints. The game might not be worth the full twenty bucks Steam is currently asking for, but it’s certainly worth picking up on sale!

23305388.review:
I don't normally write reviews for games that I play, however this game was so enjoyable that I decided it was worth the time to write a review so others who are thinking about purchasing this game can make a decision. 

Normally I play a game for a few hours and go do something else and half the time end up forgetting to ever go back to the game because the plot isn't interesting enough to keep me playing. This is one of the few games that had me so hooked I ended up playing the entire thing in one sitting. The characters are lovable and the story is cute and entertaining. The dialog can be a little long at the beginning where you feel like there is not much going on other than speaking to everyone and everything. (which I personally didn't mind but my younger sister got bored in the first 3 minutes... because she wants everything now!) However, the dialog is amusing and has many little quips that are referring to some other movies, tv shows, ect that you will hear and maybe crack a smile because you will have that 'a hah! That's from *insert reference here*' The artwork is also very well done and is primarily cartoon like but not over the top.

23280036.review:
The Book of Unwritten Tales is a classic Point & Click Adventure. It follows the paths of the gnome Wilbur, the human Nate, the elf Ivo and the Critter on their journey to save the world after the archaeologist Mortimer McGuffin finds a powerful artifact, that can decide the war between the Army of Shadows and the Alliance.
The story sounds very clichee, but that is wanted, because the Book of Unwritten Tales is just one big parody of everything that has to do with fantasy, science fiction or adventure movies and is filled with many references to them. Even the music sometimes sound suspiciously close to some of Hollywood´s classics.
The design of the game is very good for a Point & Click Adventure and fits the mood of the game very well. The 60 locations all have their own feel to them so that the game does not get boring. The Book of Unwritten Tales also did not fall for the trap, that many Point´n Clicks cannot avoid to step in. There are no annoying and unlogical puzzles. After some thinking everything makes sense, so that you do not have to randomly combine items without a certain goal. All in all the Book of Unwritten Tales was a really nice experience, that took me about thirteen hours to complete.

23252406.review:
I love this game. The puzzles aren't as crazily difficult like the Deponia series but are solvable by using simple intuition and the Spacebar. I enjoy solving the puzzles but they are more of a "If you can't do this, keep clicking on any other available spot"

PROS
1. Good Graphics
The 3D is a step up from the cartoonish drawings of the Deponia Series.

2. Interesting World
Transport Dragons, Mummies, Elves, Gnomes, Orcs, Mages and Death himself.

3. Good Title
Book of Unwritten Tales. Very catchy.

4. Weird Ideas
Using a Telephone Booth (aka Tardis concept) to teleport? Interesting.

CONS
1. Linearity
There is really only 1 way to solve a puzzle and your choices don't really matter at all. You are just solving one puzzle to get to the next.

2. Dead World
You can't interact with anything except what the developers want you to interact with. There is nothing that you can interact with for fun.

3. Colour Issues
When you make a potion, purple is not pink.

4. Number of Stirs
How do you count 3 stirs clockwise? Why is not stirring considered a foul?

5. Abrupt Ending
The ending was so easy and abrupt.

SUGGESTIONS
1. Removing the Linearity
I would suggest referring to the Witcher series for examples on how to use multiple ways to solve one issue. Or the Osbourne kids' books.

2. The Mighty Card Game
It would have been great to have a real Mighty card game within this game.

There were a few issues with subtitles mismatching and lines going through the screen where action would later take place, but they weren't distracting. There was also one or two times where I could click on something from a previous screen, which was... interesting. Again, that didn't distract from the story and just made me chuckle and move on.  There are some fantastic references that had me laughing and looking for others. 

I only remember being frustrated with a puzzle twice, and both of them were simply because the solution was too specific and illogical (they may be references?).  They didn't completely ruin the game, but they were the times where I had to consult a walkthrough which I do not like doing, but they frustrated me too much to find the real solution. Specifically [spoiler] When trying to get red paint - there is red powder that obviously needs to get wet: I came across 2 sources of water, the paladins spit and a giant tub of water in the caves, and neither worked, I needed the tiny puddle of tears that I completely missed in the crypt.  Also, needed a gold coin for the [strike] phone booth [/strike] teleporter.  Ran up to grab some from the giant piles by the throne room, but nope, I need to get into that specific locked chest - actually didn't need a walkthrough for this one - it just seemed like a silly solution [/spoiler].  In the grand scheme of the game, these are nothing, and like I said, may be references that I don't know/remember. All the other puzzles were well balanced.

I found it a solid point and click adventure with a fun story, faintly amusing jokes and hat tips to other games/stories, and a mix of easy and difficult puzzles. The puzzles ranged from collecting things from different locations to figuring out how to sneak past things. There were no hidden object scenes and logic puzzles were very minimal.

[b]However, there are some hefty flaws.[/b]

I would have liked to see a wider mix, and as a seasoned point and clicker I was disappointed.

22721983.review:
Summary: a fantastic story hindered considerably by sub-par controls.

There are already over a thousand reviews, mostly positive, so i'll just recap a few points (some of which are specific to Linux):

- notable video resolution detection/restoration problems on linux. Workaround: set up the game to run in the same resolution as your desktop does. Anything else is likely to Cause Grief.

- the controls are annoying at times, e.g., you can't select any inventory items while you're waiting on a current speaker or animation to finish (and it's not always clear when animations are finished). There are many superfluously long animations. A good half of the clickables in any given scene have no game effect, they just drag out the story.

- though the space bar can be used to show activatable/investigatable zones, this is horribly unconfortable for a game which is otherwise playable with a single hand. It "would be nice" to have a toggle option which turns (and leaves) this display on/off.

- activatable/investigatable zones sometimes overlap with the inventory activation zone (bottom of the screen), making them nearly impossible to activate (one has to fight for a while against the inventory list, which pops up automatically when the mouse hits the botton of the screen). That's is, i dare say, an epic failure.

- whether or not an item/zone can be activated cannot be determined via mouse-over while an animation/speaker is ongoing. You've got to wait until they're done before checking. Clicking bypasses a speaker, but you then risk missing important information. Which reminds me...

- the inability to pause it during speaking sequences (in particular, the early-game ones can be effing long) is problematic when the telephone rings or the neighbor decides to mow his lawn right outside your window, interrupting your game (with no way to repeat what you just missed). Another major usability fail.

- a "hint" button would be a big help. Apparently there is no way to bypass being stuck without reading a walkthrough, but....

- the game only runs in full-screen and alt-tabbing out of it sometimes corrupts its awareness of the mouse, making it impossible to click on anything when returning to the game. In such cases, only Alt-F4 (close window) helps.

- having to click some activation zones multiple times to get to the point is tremendously annoying. e.g. the first click might just tell you what it is. The second click might tell you more about it. The third click might actually let you do something with it. This causes a lot of repeat clicking on items which do _not_ require multiple clicks, as we are forced to click multiple times in order to determine whether multiple clicks are needed for that specific item. Aaarrrggg.


If the story wasn't so entertaining, i'd have stopped playing by now because the quirks of the controls are so frustrating.

21538155.review:
Very well-made point and click adventure that really sets itself apart from other games in the genre by featuring highly detailed and animated areas as well as great voice acting.

Book of Unwritten Tales claims to be full of humor through parodies to well-known fantasy material.  You'll notice more than enough references to Tolkien's Lord of the Ring, plus a bit of Terry Pratchett's Discworld, Harry Power, Indiana Jones, Doctor Who, and of course RPGs or other geekery in general.  I wouldn't say the references are all that humorous, nor are they even a decent attempt at humor.  The vast majority of the jokes are, "Hey players, look at how we are obviously referencing ______ here!"  The jokes fail to be funny on their own, so if you are not familiar with each and every reference, most of the dialogue will seem to be nothing more than idle chatter.   Even if you are familiar with the references, you probably won't find them funny.

The puzzles are not particularly challenging to figure out, especially since you're pretty much guaranteed to succeed so long as you interact with all available objects.  This becomes quite the chore in the larger areas as you have to sit there and listen to the dialogue for every single item on the screen.  You could of course skip the dialogue, but for an adventure game, if you're going to skip the dialogue you may as well not even play the game.  Chapter 4 becomes particularly tedious as you are required to trek back and forth across the map numerous times.  To make that even worse, two of the puzzles can only be solved with trail and error, so you may be making the same trek multiple times.  Pressing the space bar reveals all interaction points in your current area, so it is never a challenge to find everything.  Sadly the use of the space bar is almost a necessity because there is nothing to indicate what you can or can't interact with as you play.

This all combines for a game that is okay enough to play in short spurts but not something I'd really want to play for long periods of time.  For a 15+ hour game, this is definitely not a good thing.  I often found myself quickly reading the subtitles so I could click through the dialogue, really doing anything I could to speed the game along.  The game starts off well enough, but by the end I found myself wondering why I even bothered to finish.  Chapter 2 has the best characters and best script.  Chapter 3 is by far the best chapter in the game in terms of puzzles.  After that, though, the game really takes a nose dive on the enjoyment scale.

I do not recommend this.

21221158.review:
A fun adventure games.  Mildly funny parody. Lots of references to Discworld, World of Warcraft, LOTR, and other fantasy themed games and culture. 

In most adventure games i have to constantly go and look what to do next in a walkthrough after i swear i've clicked each item in my inventory on every other clickable thing in the game world.  This one is simple enough I can figure it out myself pretty easily.  You can take that as a Plus or a Minus depending on how difficult you like it. 

I haven't completed it, but so far i have played as 4 different characters in about 8 different area's.  It keeps it interesting seeing the gameworld through different perspectives.  

All in all a decent point and click puzzle adventure.

Recomended this to my brother when it was on sale on Steam - a week later he got The Book of Unwritten Tales 2 at full prize....  (I'm doing Rise of the Tomb Raider now - but will buy the follow up even at full prize when I have some free time).

20836687.review:
Any game that uses "In The Hall of The Mountain King" (from Peer Gynt/composed by Edvard Grieg) as backgound music in a dwarf bar is already right up my alley (so to speak) humor wise.  Of course all the parody lines from classic movies like Platoon, Stars Wars, and Lord of the Rings, plus the whole MMORPG and RPG buffing parodies, a bit of 4th wall breaking and a few omages like Discworld's Death (Terry Pratchett), Raiders of the Lost Ark and Planet of the Apes (the original Charleston Heston version) make this game's blatant to subtle parody humor all that much better.  The game, itself, is even better then its humor. 

Storyline: Wilbur Weathervane, gnome, wannabe wizard, adventure day-dreamer, sometimes tinkerer, and full time employee at a dwarf bar gets the chance of his lifetime when Mortimer MacGuffin's (gremlim, archaeologist and chronicler) prison cage literally nearly drops on his head and hands him the ONE RING, before "quest" tasking him with delivering the ONE RING to the Arch-Mage Allister in Seastone before the Arch-Witch can get it.  Mortimer, the gremlin, who had been "freed" by the wood elf, Ivo (incognito Princess and wannabe adventurer) is recaptured and taken to the Arch-Witch, who of course is the cause of the endless war since she wants to rule the world.  Meanwhile, Ivo has also been given a "quest" task by Mortimer while she was freeing his cage from the cargo dragon.  Ivo is to find and retrieve a book, which has directions to the amulet of ultimate power, from the gremlin's secret cellar and take it to the Arch-Mage Allister in Seastone.  While all this is happening Munkus, the Arch-Witch's son is hot on the trail of finding the amulet of ultimate power so he can over-throw his mother and be in control of the world instead.    

Gameplay: Point and Click adventure with a build and use inventory of items.  The gameplay is easy to follow and the tasks/obstacles are very logical given the circumstances (and people involved).  There are a few objects that are "well hidden" but if the gamer thinks for a bit, the object needed is easy to locate. (Careful searching will also accomplish the same task.)  Any encountered character gives clues about the task at hand and the main character will basically tell the the gamer what needs to be done and often times what is needed to accomplish the task.

The gamer will eventually play as four different characters, all with their own perspective, personality and knowledge that each character would possess due to their background.  In one area the gamer even has a choice of one of three characters to play, and each character solves the task at hand differently using their natural abilities.   

There are 5 chapters total.  During any chapter the gamer might play as a completely different character doing a completely separate task, once another character has finished their objective. There are also places when two (in one place three) characters are available to play at the same time by switching between them.  In these areas one character is capable of performing certain tasks the other character is not.  Also the knowledge each character possesses is clearly seen/heard.  The characters must work as a team to complete the task, and often times need to talk with each other to share knowledge and to trade inventory items.      

Overall, wonderful game, superb witty humor and an excellent story of unlikely heroes.  Well worth full price.

Note: This is the first of two games and there are DLCs available.

20830030.review: Amazing, beautiful, story rich, and engaging.  You can't get better than this for a point and click game.  Yes, sometimes you can get a bit stuck and have to look up a walkthrough, but for the most part, if you are familar with P&C, you will be fine.  The graphics are beautiful, and the story line is great.  There is lots of humor and cheeky references to other video games, but it doesn't seem forced.  Get this game, then get the other 2!  You won't be dissapointed.

20793985.review: Appena conclusa dopo poco più di 12 ore di gioco. Assolutamente consigliato, la storia è molto carina ma sopratutto tutti i personaggi con i quali entreremo in contatto hanno una caratterizzazione unica e divertente. Molto humor alla Monkey Island al quale strizza l'occhio più di una volta. Ma in generale prende in giro e si prende giro delle avventure grafiche classiche. Da giocare ed innamorarsi, esce spesso in bundle o comunque scontato, è buona cosa metterlo nella lista dei desideri! Come ultima nota, voci (in inglese) e musica di sottofondo azzeccatissime, semplicmente coinvolgenti.

20749411.review:
Wer ein Fan von Point & Click Adventures ist, wird um dieses Spiel nicht herum kommen - und sollte es auch nicht, denn es ist absolut großartig!

Man begleitet die Elfe Ivo, den Gnom Wilbur, den Menschen Nate und seinen Begleiter das Vieh durch eine fantasievolle Welt. Teilweise spielt man nur mit einem Charakter, mal auch mit mehreren und muss so kombinieren, wer an welcher Stelle was machen und mit wem sprechen muss, um weiter zu kommen.

Die Rätsel sind zu Beginn leicht zu lösen, mit der Zeit werden sie jedoch anspruchsvoller. Teilweise bin ich ein wenig umher geirrt, bis ich dann doch die richtige Person nochmal gesprochen oder die richtigen Items im Inventar kombiniert habe. Gelegentlich habe ich auch in einer Komplettlösung nachschauen müssen, weil ich den Wald vor lauter Bäume nicht gesehen habe. :D
Andererseits gibt es auch Rätsel, bei denen einen schon recht früh klar ist, worauf das hinauslaufen wird, sodass da jede Menge Abwechslung geboten wird.

Die Story ist packend und ich musste unbedingt weiter spielen, weil ich unbedingt wissen wollte, wie es weiter geht und was für Geheimnisse noch zu Tage treten. Vor allem, weil man unterschiedliche Charaktere spielen kann, lernt man unterschiedliche Sichtweisen kennen und jeder der Charaktere hat seinen ganz eigenen Humor.

Der größte Pluspunkt des Spiels ist aber definitiv der Humor. Wer in der Fantasywelt etwas bewandert ist, wird so viele Anlehnungen an bekannte Werke finden, z.B. Herr der Ringe, Harry Potter, World of Warcraft... Es ist eine große Freude die Charaktere in den Unterhaltungen zu erleben. Ich war während des Spielens durchgehend am glucksen und lachen, weil das Spiel einfach so liebevoll umgesetzt wurde.

Pro:
- mehrere Charaktere
- abwechslungsreiche Rätsel
- schöne Grafik
- tolle Story
- unglaublich viel Humor

Contra:
- es gibt leider kein Questbuch

Fazit:
Das Spiel ist absolut zu empfehlen.
In meinen Augen gehört es zu den besten Point & Click Adventures, die ich bisher gespielt habe.

Noch ein kleiner Tipp:
Es lohnt sich relativ zu Beginn in Wilburs Zuhause den Stuhl anzuklicken. :D

20741572.review:
Found it quite fun. I think it took me about 20 hours and I had very few boring moments. The main character, the Gnome, is charming and fun to play. PARENTS: in my opinion, it is fine for 8 years or older; or 12 years old if you are very conservative (there is one adult-ish or teen joke, though a child might really not notice at all).

PRICE matters: I bought BOUT I, II and the Critter Chronicles (Prequel) as a cheap bundle. I would not pay over 15$ for this game alone (as a maximal price only; otherwise find a bundle or wait for a sale).

I suggest playing the Prequel first. BOUT I is better in terms of story and style in my opinion, but the Prequel will give Critter an interesting background when you play BOUT I (Critter has no background or known concept when you play BOUT I).

20524671.review:
I really wanted to like this game, it has nice graphics and good voice over and the music is very enjoyable. 

And here it comes the: Buuuuuuuut
For me personally, it's let down by too many quests in quests.... it started needing one item that needed a few quests completed to get the item, fine, I'm all for a few quests, but then it turns out that the items needed required even more quests or even two quests. then hurray! You get the item, then, you have to do more quests for the next set of items, ad nauseum... ugh, that just made it feel daunting, I managed to drag myself thru this game and the best part for me (sorry to say) was the end credits....
It has a lot of bigoted views in it too, I won't mention which here as they can be offensive, and it also seems to mock popular culture giants rather than embody them as a good parody.

For me, it's too annoying to do quest in quest in quest, it feels like too much unneeded work and the bad elements really put one off enjoying the rest of the game, I'm a huge fan of point and clicks like Monkey Island and Deponia, and as I say, I wanted to like this one, but it's just unlikable.

For some it may be a great game, if they can ignore the quest in quest and slurs, but it's not for me :)

20361911.review: Eccezionale. Adventure con grafica meravigliosa, storia accattivante, personaggi che ti prendono, humor azzeccato. Per esempio, il Critter sicuramente è destinato ad essere un'altra icona nel panorame videoludico, e forse, anche i vari Ivo e company. I richiami ad altre adventure cult arricchiscono l'atmosfera ironica del gioco. Il sonoro è buono. Una adventure che può benissimo essere a fianco delle blasonate del genere, di quelle che hanno fatto la storia delle adventure, come Monkey Island, senza paura di essere sacrileghi (ma che, forse la mania di aspirare ad essere pirati si sia propagata in giro? ). In più, anche se la versione steam non prevede la traduzione in italiano, è facile procurarsi in giro la patch della traduzione. Gli enigmi sono alla portata del giocatore medio. Da non perdere.

20331579.review:
J'avais commencé par regarder 5mn de la soluce (soit l'intro et la première énigme) de BoUT 2 avant d'arrêter la vidéo de l'acheter et de me régaler. J'ai acheté celui là parce que ce genre de jeu, on en veut encore et encore. Et bien je n'ai pas été déçu ! 19h de pur régal en plus des 39 sur l'autre volet.

J'espère que l'équipe va nous pondre un autre bijou avec ou sans ces personnage d'ailleurs. Lucas Arts nous avait "donné du rêve" dans les 90's mais n'a plus les tripes nécessaires pour sortir des bijoux d'aventures. Nordic Games/King Art a repris le flambeau.

Merci ! Encore !

Note : ce jeu  comporte un bug touchant au son. Je le conseille en promo jusqu'à ce que les devs mettent le nez dans le cambouis pour le corriger (un problème lié au démarrage d'OpenAL)

Si le jeu crashe au lancement, pour le lancer :
- fermez toute fenêtres. Sans exceptions.
- Lancez le jeu avec un clic droit sur le mini icone de steam.
- Il va planter.
- Fermer la fenêtre sans rechercher de solution puis relancez le immédiatement le jeu de la même façon (vous disposez de quelques secondes, une petite dizaines je pense).

20002809.review:
Me lembrou os bons tempos dos adventures de comédia da Lucas Arts dos anos 90. O jogo começa com uma pegada de aventura e traz personagens simpáticos que cativam logo de cara. A história é legal, uma fantasia meio manjada, mas que não se vê tanto ultimamente. O jogo tem várias referências à cultura pop-nerd, com uma pegada Tolkieana misturado com Monkey Island. O que frustra um pouco são os puzzles. Algumas coisas sem sentido, sem muito propósito a não ser fazer o jogador andar pra lá e pra cá nos mesmos cenários atrás de detalhes que passaram despercebidos, pra conseguir alguma coisa de um NPC chato que não está disposto a ajudar se não conseguir uma série de itens. O jogo começa bem, se perde no meio, mas volta a ficar interessante no final, que ficou muito bom, deixando então uma impressão boa.

NOTA: 8/10

19933175.review:
It's too blunt for my taste in its desperate attempts to live up to its role models, the legendary Lucasfilm adventures. I hardly made it over the first some puzzles, as the cheese hit me pretty hard: When a bullwhip was introduced rather heavy-handed, the elf girl comments the use of it with a whistling of the Indiana Jones theme. This fanservice was very telegraphed and as the game wasn't too impressive yet, i didn't want to go on.

For Lucasfilm-style Adventure-Fans, this is a nice game. For anybody expecting stories and dialogs mature enough to stand on its own feet, this is a little hard to swallow.

19776810.review:
Initial impression was positive, before the sexism, homophobia and transphobia went off the charts in chapter 4 when you have to play as Captain Nate.

Game mechanics: Switching between characters is an exercise in patience as they walk around aimlessly for awhile before hand off. Voice acting is excellent. The character movements are cool (except when switching characters.) Despite Ivo's ridiculous scantily clad girl-elf armor, she's a pretty interesting character, and the brains of the party. Wilbur is reasonably clever too. Many secondary characters are interesting, like the little rat warrior. Storyline is highly engaging, and the puzzles, while sometimes tedious or frustrating in the usual point-and-click manner, are mostly interesting and fun.

Further into the game - chapter 4 - you're stuck being Captain Nate. Captain Nate is a jerk. He is such a jerk that I'm having a hard time progressing in the game now that I'm forced to interact through him. 

Captain Nate objectifies all the women he interacts with. They're just sex objects to him, so I'm a bit bewildered by the "girl power" tag associated with this game. He cuts down everyone around him like an insecure school boy. He goes on and on about what it means to be "a man" in this archaic, tedious litany of outdated stereotypes ... I'm just so sick of the culture remnants of shaming people who don't fit some stupid cultural concept of "normal." This guy is desperate to be "normal" where normal is some kind of ignorant, chauvinstic male pig and proving it at every turn. I think it might have been intended as humor? If so, it failed. Badly.

There's a character in Captain Nate's sequence who's a pink-clad paladin with high heels on his pink banner. I'm all for flipping paladins shit as a timeworn gamer tradition, but this was deeply inappropriate. Liking pink doesn't make you weak. Wearing heels doesn't make you weak. Besides the obvious misogyny and sexism of demeaning femme-stereotyped gender stuff, it's also a train wreck of genderqueer shaming and pacificist shaming. I'm so done with this kind of thing in our culture. Teenagers kill themselves over "humor" like this. Leelah Alcorn didn't have a chance because of attitudes like this. Stop it. It's shaming and bullying and it's time for us to be better people. I keep trying to get through these scenes with Nate and the pink paladin, hoping that there will be some kind of redemption, but it just keeps not happening, and I'm running out of patience.

This is 3 quarters of a really good adventure game. It's charming and witty, and with just the right difficulty level for three chapters. Unfortunately the fourth chapter lets it down: least interesting player character, most frustrating puzzles (a water source used in one puzzle can't be used in another puzzle for no logical reason), missing translations (some WoW references went untranslated) and a completely out-of-place rhythm mini-game for which no instructions are provided (turns out the helpful target area is just wrong, which made me incorrectly assume that the arrow keys didn't work for it).

I enjoyed it, it took me about 16 hours to complete, I had to look up walkthroughts sometimes as I couldn't find some item I needed to get to the next stage.

Good quality game. 
Beautiful artwork, the levels are all really well done and nice to look at. 
Funny, there are a lot of jokes, some of them are at you the player. 
Good voice acting, there is a lot of dialogue and they don't repeat themselves much unless you do the same thing over and over, makes the game interesting. 
Interesting story line, the characters seem pretty alive.

A bit unpolished
Gameplay gets a bit tedious, you have to solve the problems exactly the way the gamemakers want which sometimes makes no sense, for example you need some coins to put in a slot machine, instead of grabbing coins from piles and piles of coins you must use coins from a particular box...it is essentially a go fetch game.
Characters look out of place, they aren't the same quality as the levels, would have liked to have a high res elf babe ;)
Some things are unpolished. The dragon seems a bit slower than the other characters. The cut scenes are lower quality than the game, seems a bit strange when you play.
The end comes too soon too easily! So I guess I enjoyed it :)

19164313.review:
Na kérem, valami ilyesmit képzelek el indie-játéknak így 2015-ben. Egy abszolút aranyos, high-fantasy környezetben játszódó point'n'click kalandjáték, jópofa szereplőkkel, vicces gegekkel, popkultúrás utalásokkal. A grafika teljesen rendben van, jellegzetesen képregényes, recék nélkül natívan fut fullHD-ban, az animációk jók, sokszor kimondottan poénosra vannak véve, a karakterek szerethetők, a szinkron teljesen oké, a többi hang rajzfilmes, a zenei eredeti és egyedi, bár felejthető de amíg játék közben szól addig tök jó. A feladatok nem nehezek, könnyen ki lehet találni mihez mi kell meg mire lesz jó, bár mindig mindenkivel beszélni kell meg megnézni meg megpróbálni hogy rendesen beadja a következő scriptet. Hibába én nem futottam. Ja, és hosszú! 10-12 óra simán, ami nem felesleges mászka, hanem rendesen a feladatok megoldása. Tökjó!
Egy nagy negatívum: nincs journal, úgyhogy vagy egyhuzamban kell végigtolni, vagy marhára emlékezni kell rá hogy hogy hol hagytuk abban, különben lehet újra végigmászkálni mindenkit. Kisebb negatívum: van benne pár qte, ami ugyan vicces animációval jár együtt, de úgyse tudsz arra figyelni, és a gombkiosztása is pocsék. Ezt leszámítva nagyon kellemes és vicces élmény volt. Van második része, azt is szívesen megnézem majd ha utamba akad.

Aloha Community,

da ich nun schon etwas länger "The Book of Unwritten Tales" spiele, habe ich mir gedacht auch mal wieder ein Review zu verfassen.

Das Spiel ist von seiner Aufmachung sehr interessanter. Es werden viele Anspielungen zu anderen Spielen, Filmen, u.Ä. direkt im Spiel verwendet, was einen gerne mal zum Schmunzeln verleitet, selbst unser Leben spielt darin eine Rolle ;-) Inwiefern solltet ihr selbst entdecken :-P

Die Grafik ist wunderbar spielerisch vereint und das Gameplay lässt keine Wünsche offen. Es ist einfach strukturiert und damit sehr leicht händelbar. Es ist eben ein typisches Adventure-Game. Die Story des Spiels ist recht amüsant, weil sich der rote Faden ständig erweitert. Die Rätsel im Spiel sind nicht zu einfach, aber auch nicht wesentlich schwer, also eine gute Mischung für geduldslose Spieler.

Ich persönlich bin von diesem Spiel sehr angetan und werde wohl auch noch die nächsten Teile spielen, gekauft sind sie schon :-D

Greets

Skal

18963962.review:
ONE OF THE BEST! (IMO)

After playing more than a fair share of (point & click) adventure games in my life from all the way back in the beginning (in the 80's) up to present time, I have to say that this goes right in amongst my all-time favorites. It is a fantastic blend of humor, lovable characters, amazing artwork, intriguing puzzles/tasks to solve and excellent writing. It pleasantly breaks the 4th wall and shower us with references to games and movies alike that especially speak to the ones of us that has grown up with these types of games. I had many many "Laugh Out Loud" moments playing through this game, and it felt proper lengthy as well.

The difficulty level was a bit up and down, and there was a handful of pixel hunts, plus quite a bit of running back and forth, but it didn't ruin the experience at all. There was so much fun going on when doing all those things that it didn't matter.

The voice acting had me a bit worried at first as it seemed a bit flat at the very beginning, but it quickly escalated and felt proper good. The Welsh English dialect seem to suit this setting very well, as it did in Ni No Kuni. The sound effects and/or animation was a bit off at times, but easy to look past that. 

I can easily recommend this game to anyone who's into adventure games, or I'd actually go as far as call this a must have for any adventure fan. It would also be a good choice for people not familiar with these types of game and want to try one out.  It is well worth the money.

Rated 9/10

Happy gaming!

J3ST3R

18810057.review:
Soundtrack und Design sind ganz cool, aber die deutsche Vertonung ist teilweise so lustlos und leider habe ich auch keine Möglichkeit gefunden auf die englische Vertonung zu wechseln gefunden.
Mein größter Kritikpunkt ist das Gameplay. Jedes Objekt, das man berühren will muss zuerst angeschaut werden und kann danach erst aufgenommen werden. Das zerstört den Spielflow, besonders wenn man mehrere spielbare Charaktere hat von denen manchmal nur ein spezieller ein Item aufheben will. Dazu kann man teilweise Items erst aufheben nachdem man eine bestimmte Aktion gemacht oder ein anderes Item aufgenommen hat, die nichts direkt mit Item zu tun haben. So kam es vor, dass ich versuchte ein Rätsel auf eine Art zu lösen - das funktionierte nicht- also lief ich ziellos im Level hin und her und kombinierte alles mit allem. Ohne Erfolg.
Also schaute ich frustiert in der Lösung nach nur um herauszufinden, dass ich mit dem Händler erst sprechen kann, wenn ich die dreckige Klobürste in einem anderen Level ein Stück nach rechts geschoben habe. (*Kein echtes Rätsel aus dem Spiel nur ein Vergleich*)
Manche Point&Click- Fans mögen dieses Design lustig finden, aber für die Mehrheit der Spieler ist das einfach nur ein übersehner Fehler im Gamedesign, der frustiert und nervt.

18778468.review:
Je joue sur Linux. Version Linux : correcte.

[h1]Le jeu[/h1]

Un excellent point & click qui ne se prends pas au sérieux, bourré d'humour.

Les plus :
[list]
[*]L'humour omniprésent.
[*]Les très nombreuses références et clin d'oeil aux films, autres jeux ou bouquins. On y retrouve Star Wars, Indiana Jones, les MMORPG en général, LotR, ....
[*]Le doublage est vraiment très bon. En anglais uniquement cela dit.
[*]Le système qui affiche les objets actifs en appuyant sur la barre espace. De plus, les objets qui ne sont plus utiles ne sont plus affichés : pas besoin de cliquer 45x sur un objet pour s'entendre dire la même chose.
[*]Aucun puzzle tordu (oui, je pense à toi et tes amis, Day of the Tentacle).
[*]Le jeu n'est pas difficile, il raconte juste une histoire banale pour de la fantasy, mais il la raconte très bien ! :).
[/list]

Les moins :
[list]
[*]Les cinématiques sont vraiment moches. Et non sous titrées. Mais très peu nombreuses heureusement !
[*]Quelques erreurs de traduction (par ci par là une ligne en allemand, ou bien une traduction un peu foireuse en français), mais rien de bien méchant.
[/list]

[h1]Rejouabilité, achievements[/h1]

Point&click linéaire, donc non, pas de rejouabilité.

[h1]En bref[/h1]

Bourré d'humour, définitivement recommandé !

[h1]GNU/Linux[/h1]

La version Linux est correcte, mais crash dans le menu options. Il y a un workaround sur les forums.

OS: Linux Mint 17.2 x64, MATE edition.
Hardware : i5 3570K OC@4.5Ghz, Nvidia 670GTX, 16GB ram.
Screens : Triplescreen, dont un vertical, configurés en screens X séparés.

ok, during the first few hours, this game was GREAT!  very recommended!  fun, interesting puzzles, a bit of pop-culture references, etc.

but then, it was the same thing.  over and over again.  jump through hoops.  know what to do ahead of time?  sorry, can't do it until you click on something or talk to someone and only THEN can you do it.  know how to do something simple?  nope, you have to do it the complicated way.  want to switch characters?  ok, but first you have to wait for the first guy to slowly walk to his "rest" spot and then wait for the other character to move to his "play" spot.

and near the end, the activities got SO TEDIOUS, and SO REPETITIVE, and SO MUNDANE, that i just resorted to cheats to get through it to the end.

it reminded me in many parts to an old game called Nibiru (2005).  i hated it, it was WAY too structured and made you feel like an untrained dog being trained to sit.

if you have children around, close the door because you WILL swear a lot.  or just let them play it.  they may not find it too pedantic.

17891776.review:
I've bought the game a couple years ago (soon after it was released), but only had the time to play it now.

And it was a blast. One of the best adventure games I ever played. It has everything a good game of this genre needs to have: memorable characters, funny conversations, captivating story and logical puzzles. The visuals are nice too, despite some flaws in animation and a few graphical glitches.

Quotes from popular culture (LotR, Star Wars, Indiana Jones, etc.) are also funny and are always spot on. The game also  occasionaly breaks the fourth wall and/or makes fun of the gaming industry (level 68 warriors with health potions) and MMORPGs is particular.

Overall, a very enjoyable experience. I will definitely be playing Critter Chronicles and The Book of Unwritten Tales 2.

17810858.review:
So many things to like about this game! Super fantastic art, great characters (especially Wilbur who is a refreshing character to play with his accent and naïveté) and voice acting, and a good story to pull you all the way through. There's a lot of content and only being moderately difficult, you're still in for 20+ hours of play. The game is quite humerous and well-written, and it's nice to see some ironic references and fourth-wall-breaking done well.

Only downsides are that I found the latter third of the game playing with Nate drags on a little bit, and the ending is a little abrupt. Forunately there's two more games to move on to, so at this point in time I'm able to be more forgiving. There is also some issues with widescreen resolutions on the game - I had to drop the resolution down and stretch the screen to actually be able to see and complete some puzzles. Occasionally walking in to a new location would slow the game down to a crawl, and I had to exit and re-enter scenes until they came right. This didn't happen too often and didn't affect my enjoyment of the game.

Overall, a fantastic and fun adventure, one that I thoroughly enjoyed. Looking forward to playing subsequent titles!

17680544.review:
This is, like, the prime example of why I'd want a "meh" button. The game isn't awful. Far from it. The graphics are passable, the voice acting is mostly decent, the music is alright, and the puzzles themselves make enough sense in-universe. The game's got a pretty decent length (maybe too long) and a good amount of humor.

But it's just... boring.

I will sum up the problem in one single image:

https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CHhDACHW8AE47M_.png:large

Do you see this? At the start of the fourth chapter, the current protagonist says this. And this is exactly what happens.

You cannot. Be. The. Thing. You. Are. Trying. To. Parody. It just does not work. You have failed as parody if you are doing the exact thing you are mocking. 

A lot of the game devolves into tedious fetch quests. The story is nothing special. It's a basic "save the world" vaguely plot. Fantasy/RPG setting. That's fine. The point is the comedy.

And it does succeed there, in some regards. The first chapter is a bit light on it, but the second chapter is just jam-packed with humor and had me playing practically straight through. It kinda comes to a halt when the story intervenes though, but for those two or three hours I had tons of fun with the game. The mage diploma, the real-world MMO, the "magic" tricks, the lampshading of death in adventure games... it's all good comedy. It's an interesting world.

And then... chapter 3 hits. Where you go through a temple in search of the plot device. No subversions. No real comedy. It's a stretch of the game where nothing really happens except more puzzles. The plot moves forward, sure, but the game has already established at this point that the plot does not matter. Why should I care about the plot. Why should I care about these characters. Wilbur is the only character that's really interesting in any way, and is why the second chapter works so well. Ivo is boring and without any personality whatsoever. Nate is an unlikeable jerk and cements his status as such at the end of the third chapter. Sure, the game calls him out for it too, but. He can be unlikeable to other characters without making him unlikeable to the audience as well.

And the real nail in the coffin. After Nate does "the bad thing" that makes him so unlikeable... he is the primary controllable character for the rest of the game. You play as Wilbur for two short scenes and Ivo/Critter for one relatively small scene. The rest is him. 

I do not want to play as the unsympathetic jerk. I actually put the game down for a week at the start of Chapter 4 because I was dreading having to play as Nate. Sure, he spends the rest of the game trying to make up for his mistake, but I don't believe it. I don't feel compelled by it. I don't like him and that's not going to change.

It doesn't help that the humor revolving around him isn't as good, nor are the characters he has to interact with. The dead lovers are kinda amusing. The paladin character and especially Nate's attitude towards him are an UTTER TRAVESTY, absolutely disgusting. The buffalo is boring. The Orc brothers are a very basic smart/stupid. The dragon is about the best character met in this chapter, but she comes in only near the end and doesn't do much, we don't see her much. Plus, her animation is pretty horrible and brings down that short section a lot.

And then... you get to replay the last section of the fourth chapter from a different perspective, hearing basically no new dialogue, visiting no new locations, and doing very few new puzzles. And then the game... ends. It doesn't even make sense how it ends, either.

SPOILER ALERT because I need to have this bit in my review.
Why did they need to bring the Earth Pixies to the tower? Why did the other three need to be there alongside Ivo? At that point, all that needed to be done was for Ivo to leave the tower. The artifact wasn't in the chest, so the villains wouldn't have it. There was an easy way for Ivo to leave the tower unnoticed and unharmed. There was no reason for the entire out-of-the-blue pixie invasion and dragon reappearance with the other, except to force that cliche fly-off-into-the-distance ending. And wasn't it established that the monstrous villain lady (who we NEVER see) is really powerful? She could slaughter those pixies - heck, probably did off-screen. And Ivo intentionally drew her attention. For what purpose? Who knows. God. Everything about the ending is completely nonsensical, even aside from the fact that it just... happens. Very abruptly. The last puzzle in the game... is shrinking an orc in a completely different location from the climax.

All-in-all... the game's a bit tedious, light on the comedy for most of the game, and overall just not a worthwhile investment of your time. It's alright, but not great. It has many, many problems. I'd say, pass.

What a marvelous game - a new grand jewel of classic adventure genre. It has good story, sophisticated humor, awesome characters, beautiful soundtrack, etc.

The plot is hardly unwritten but it surely is very well told. The evil creature 'Mother' lurks in her heinous tower and tries to get her hands on a special relic with which she could take over the world. Game's 4 main characters get involved to events - whether they want it or not. Becoming from different parts of the world and having diffrent values their paths cross and will eventually become friends. Unlike in some other games of the genre - every playable character of The book of Unwritten Tales' is interesting and I always kept thinking that how they end up. Toast for the talented voice actors!

The puzzles are typical point&click. While writing this review no particularly annoying puzzle is reaching my mind - there was however one itchy stealth event at the midway which did not fit in the game so well, but provided some variation perhaps. Some people have claimed that the game is even too easy when pointing the places of interest for player, for example. On the other hand I can quarantee that this is still much more challenging than some of modern adventure games of Telltale.

The Book of Unwritten Tales has already proved its potential and the sequel has already been released! So if you have a thing with point&click and like adventure - Don't let this book to be unread! ;)

Ich bin eigentlich eher ein Spieler von Horror-Adventures und konnte zum Beispiel mit den Spielen von Tim Schafer wie Monkey Island wenig anfangen, da sie doch eher infantil albern waren. Aber The Book of Unwritten Tales ist einfach witzig. Intelligent, vielseitig, charmant und urkomisch. Dazu gibt es sehr viele hübsche Areale, interessante Charaktäre, eine hervorragende deutsche Synchro und einen tollen Soundtrack. Schon im ersten Abschnitt deutete sich an, dass es sich einen Platz unter meinen Favoriten im Adventure-Genre sichert und spätestens als Wilbur von seinem Großvater nach Seefels transportiert wurde oder als man das Kaninchen fangen sollte, konnte ich mich vor Lachen nicht mehr halten. 

Dementsprechend empfehle ich dieses Spiel jedem, der einen Hauch von Interesse an Point&Click-Adventures hat. Trotz des deutlich eintönigeren Prequels "The Critter Chronicles" werde ich mir mit Sicherheit bald den zweiten Teil zu Gemüte führen.

17517420.review:
First off, I  want to mention that I finished this game. Being a game that can last up to 20 hours the majority of my time was offline. 

                 Hark back to the days of adventure, by clicking on random pixels, picking up items, and combining items in random or "logical" ways in hopes of finding your way through the adventure. This game is a throwback. A "Point and Click" adventure game. While there have been many since the days of Monkey Island, and even in recent years, this is probably one of the best since Monkey Island. 

                  You take the role of a young gnome named Wilbur who yearns for adventure and hopes to remove himself from his menial life, the beautiful elf Ivo who just so happened to be in the right place at the right time, and a wise-cracking cocky human with a peculiar past named Nate. Nate on the run from a bounty hunter has a furry sidekick called "Critter" whom speaks nothing but nonesense (familiar?). 
 
                Spoilers:  The adventure begins with a ring...among the backdrop of a war between the Alliance (gnome, dwarf, human...) and an army of orcs. 

                  I'll stop my spoilers there. It should sound familiar to you. This game is humurous, using obvious references to help out its humor, but it doesn't over do it. A wonderously funny game in its own right, It doesn't bash nor does it even spoof what it references. It's good natured ribbing over the typical Toklien-esque fantasy world, and certain games and films we've all come to know through the years, but again it doesn't over do it.  It brings up some good points about gaming in general though, mainly directed at the MMORPG when Wilbur asks "Why would people feel the need to leave their real-life to play a fictitious life...." That's not a direct quote, but it was along the same lines. Most likely done in jest,  to me it still brings up a good question about our hobby. 

                   The art style is superb. Bright colors and details abound, and I caught myself wishing there was a 3D space to it, to be able to explore more deeply than you're able in the game. The dialogue is also detailed. Click on certain items on-screen, and you'll get a simple explanation of it, but enough that it may give you a nice background and history of the world. Even minor points of interest, and minor characters have some history and background to them. In summary, this is just a nice game with lots of spirit. Beautiful artwork, clever dialogue, and never a time of frustration, it deserves your attention. I've been gaming since I was a kid,  this is one of my favorites.

                     P.S. Soapbox time: As for Wilbur's question, we all have our reasons to "game." I've been lucky enough to travel and have real life adventures in this world. I SEEK it out. What motivated me to do all that? Playing games as a child. The fantasy and the worlds I got sucked into, it motivated me to find it in real life. Hope you all seek your adventures just the same.

17238019.review:
A lovely adventure game somewhat betrayed by its simplicity.

Throughout the course of the game you gain control of 3 characters (you can maybe count it as 4 even), playing some sections exclusively as one character, or sometimes getting the option of switching to another. All three are fun to play and have their own distinct personalities which also translate into their observations of the world, which you can directly see by inspecting the same items with different characters. Although the last one you are introduced to does take a little while to like, since at the beginning he's quite obnoxious.

The story is one of the most important parts in an adventure game, and here it certainly does not disappoint. It is a lighthearted save the world plot spanning through a diverse set of areas with a real feeling of adventure. However the ending did feel rushed, and compared to the rest of the game the're just the feeling that not as much thought went into designing it.

The biggest problem the game has is that there is only one usable button, you do absolutely everything with only the left mouse click. This means that even if you get stuck somewhere, it is not too difficult to brute force your way through, because there is a much more limited number of possibilities than in traditional adventure games.

But perhaps there is some sort of an upshot to this as well. The game flow is rarely interrupted and you're not going to get frustrated over some random puzzle, although there is one particularly annoying area in a mine which for some reason uses a top down camera instead of the traditional sidescrolling one.

The Book of Unwritten Tales is certainly lengthy enough without the need for convoluted puzzles, it took me 13 hours to finish it, but I didn't spend much of that time trying to figure out what to do next.

7 / 10

The Book of Unwritten Tales is a entertaining and competent point and click adventure game. A proper widescreen mode would have been nice but the visuals outside of that is charming. I also enjoyed the voice acting and i have no real complaints on the presentation outside of the 4:3 ratio nonsense.

I enjoyed the puzzles in the game and for the most part i found them to be at a reasonable level of being far fetched. There is also an option to highlight interactable object which i enjoyed having. And overall i would say that the point and click part of the game was enjoyable enough and worked as it should.

Storywise i would say that the game is a bit of a mixed bag. There are a lot of enjoyable characters and situations in the game and i did enjoy that you got to play as multiple characters. The gnome in particular was really charming. There was also a bunch of references and jokes which i greatly enjoyed.

The story though is not really all that great and it has a bit of a pacing problem. This is not a huge issue but i feel that there is room for improvements when it comes to the overarching plot of the game. 

But overall i enjoyed the game and i would recommend the game or the demo for anyone looking for a fun and lighthearted point and click game.

17077424.review:
I wasn't sure about this at first, as it's a little uneven in the early going, but the longer I played it, the more I enjoyed it. It's a fairly standard fantasy point-and-click adventure, where there's a big bad guy trying to get a powerful magic item, but it has a number of features that make it more entertaining than what you'd expect from such a generic situation.

One of the best innovations I've seen in a while is that hotspots will disappear after you've done everything possible with them. That really helps eliminate wasteful backtracking and double-checking of red herrings. You also switch around between three characters, all with totally different personalities and abilities. It's a bit reminiscent of older LucasArts games like Maniac Mansion and Zak McKracken. These two features help keep the game moving.

The other thing that sets this game apart is its excellent sense of humor. The game walks a fine line between meta-humor and camp while playing with genre tropes and expectations from RPGs and graphical adventure games. Fantasy geeks will appreciate all the jokes referencing other games, books, and movies. The voice acting is also very good, which helps with the delivery of a lot of the humorous lines.

The 3D graphics are mostly good, although there is some clipping and other weirdness here and there, and the cutscenes are only fair. Scenes are shown from widely varying angles to allow access to everything you need, which is appreciated.

It took me twelve hours to complete, and I feel like I went at a fairly steady pace, so I'd expect 10-15 hours for almost anyone to finish it. Overall, any experienced adventurers will enjoy the game quite a bit, and it's easy to recommend for such folks.

The voice work is well done, even though the plot is very, obviously, cheesy. Looking forward to the sequel.

16698951.review:
As a big fan of adventure games, I've been looking for a good one on Steam. I was horribly disappointed by the animations of the Monkey Island HD editions and the unintuitive controls or inability to skip narrated dialog. I was very frustarted at the lunacy of Deponia - puzzles so bizarre that solving them was a game of exhaustive trial and error (or basically dependent upon using a guide).

Unwritten Tales sits somewhere between the two. It's not perfect, but it is good enough to enjoy. The voice acting is good, the scenes look good and the puzzles are fairly logical. There's good features like double clicking an exit to skip the walking to it - so there is not much time spent waiting for characters to traverse scenes (and generally there's not absurdly long routes in any particular scene or area unlike Deponia). You can show all the hotspots by pressing the space bar, which is needed because a few of the things you need are pretty small or obscured. It plays well overall.

It does have issues. I've run into a few glitches already. Some of the models look either dated or amateur - especially when animated. A lot of the animations are a bit off, but nothing so bad that it ruins the experience (unlike the Monkey Island HD games). Depsite these, I'm enjoying it so far.

16298984.review:
One of the most important things about making jokes is timing, in particular when it comes to breaking the fourth wall. Break it too often, the wall will eventually crumble, and the mechanic stops being funny.

Unfortunately BOUT suffer from this problem. The forth wall is a particular important wall when it comes to maintaining the game's universe as a credible world different from the world of the player. Because the fourth wall is so utterly destroyed by the game itself, immersion into the game universe becomes impossible. This leads to a reduction in the experience, so the game becomes what a classic P&C game is at the mechanical core. A string of puzzles where certain objects must be combined in the right order to progress the story.

In good P&C games, the attention of the player is directed away from the core puzzle mechanic by an engaging story, and immersive environment.

Immersion is very often what makes the story believable and engaging, and because immersion is destroyed in BOUT, the story seems generally weak, and the mechanics of the strung together puzzles comes to the forefront. That it is just a puzzle game is not hidden behind the immersive story.

One of the most important things about a P&C is that you can trust the characters ad the game when it comes to the hints and help it offers when trying to solve a particular puzzle. The game should never give you information that is misleading. It can keep information from you, but shouldn't make the player feel cheated or lied to. BOUT has a couple of these instances, but generally the puzzles are logical and reasonable.

It has been claimed that the female elf is needlessly sexualized in BOUT. To that I have to ask: have you seen her move? Just because she wears very little clothing, doesn't mean that she is sexualized, or presented as a mere sexual being, with no other purpose than being visual stimulation for the male gaze. To this male gazer, there is very little sexual about her.

It has a few graphical glitches, but nothing game breaking in my playthrough.

As long as you treat BOUT as primarily a puzzler, and less a P&C with a story, you'll have a few good hours of entertainment. As a P&C adventure, I can't recommend the game. As a puzzler with commentary, it's quite good. Not a difficult puzzler, but good for relaxed playing with a smile or laugh here and there.

16204466.review:
Tedious.

I played through the prologue and it was all right. Nothing really exciting, but it kept me playing.
Unfortunately, quite soon the game reveals itself to be a completely uninspired pile of overplayed references.

Such a title could keep you hooked by trying to throw some humorous puzzles that are actually fantasy themed.
For example you may have to send dragons to eat a shepherd's sheep to please his neighboring farmer, and have the dragon be upset by the sheep bleating and do something unexpected, or have the farmer upset with you because the dragon burned down his barley in the process.. but the game will not give you any of that.
Instead you'll have to find a way to take a guardsman's sandwich by beating him at a round of an RPG cards game or make turns around a young tree until the protagonist will finally understand that he should make a wand out of it. 
Ultimately: not an exiting scenario at all, especially by the time anything gets finally done.

As for the playing itself: too many times you have to go back to npc X to realize that a new dialogue option has been enabled or something new can happen in a screen you have already inspected before.
Not only this but the (already uninspired) tasks stick around way too much: you solved a puzzle and guess what, you have to solve it again in a different way and again...

 ...if you're looking for some mix and match puzzles in a funny scenario, do yourself a favor and look elsewhere.

16141630.review:
Wow, how have I not played this until now? Not sure if it's referred to as a "cult classic" but it should be! I haven't got one single bad thing to say about this. The puzzles were not obtuse, nor did they require random clicking to get the stars to align (levers all up/all lights green etc - there is one green light thingy, but it does make sense, I promise!). Well it's not random in most games I guess, but most of the time you can solve them by bowing to the gods of RNG. 
Anyway, yes, the puzzles. Lovely. Also, unlike Daedalic, they help you by keeping your area of investigation quite small, so you can focus on the task at hand, and not wander lost in 10 different areas. You can enable visible hotspots which is nice. Best part is, if you look at them and they're not usable, they'll disappear. No clutter! :) 
And ohhh, the humor! You have zombie love, time travelling, LOTR references, RPG references (dating back to the text-based ones even), making fun of the ridiculous music puzzles we've all experienced and so much more! (like vegetarian dragons, which are always a nice touch)

Characters are all nice, and the good news is you'll play 4 of them! Voice acting is amazing, artwork is beautiful - you'll love MacGuffin's house in the woods!  

This is a MUST - and it won't be even a tiny bit frustrating, which is so rare in adventure games.

15875275.review:
Voici un point & click original ! L'univers héroïc-fantasy n'est pas sans rappeler bien sûr le Seigneur des Anneaux, mais surtout dans son décalage l'univers du Disque-Monde.

Si vous aimez l'héroïc-fantasy et les point & click, c'est un jeu à faire !
La durée de jeu est d'environ 14-15h (en comptant donc les tâtonnements).

Parmi les points forts :
- des décors très immersifs
- des musiques simples mais efficaces qui correspondent parfaitement au type de jeu et à l'ambiance
- beaucoup d'humour décalé et des gags très drôles

Parmi les points faibles :
- très linéaire, pas de easter egg ou de quêtes annexes, on ne peut s'y prendre que d'une façon...
- ... et parfois les énigmes sont totalement tirées par les cheveux (par exemple quand vous avez besoin de combiner un objet avec de l'eau, il faut user d'une seule façon d'obtenir de l'eau), ce qui rend parfois le jeu frustrant
- un vrai problème de rythme à certains moments, notamment au chapitre 4, qui ne devient qu'une course aux objets en tout genre où l'on voit peu l'intérêt et où cela n'est pas relevé par une blague par exemple

Sans le compter comme un point faible, il y a aussi l'impossibilité de revoir les phrases dites juste avant à propos d'un objet, et dont on aurait oublié ce qu'il faut en faire ou à quoi il correspond. C'est aussi le cas pour les dialogues que l'on ne peut pas revoir la plupart du temps.

Mais cela reste un très bon jeu, aussi je vous le recommande chaudement si jamais vous voulez un jeu pas trop long, mais qui laisse le temps d'établir un petit scénario sympa et drôle :)

15854397.review:
《未传之书》是德国工作室 KING Art 2011年的作品，Steam上还有一部前传和续作，ChinaAVG上应该有汉化。本作个人感觉是个7~7.5/10分的作品，有点像奇幻版的《猴岛小英雄》，游戏里也有一些致敬的成分。

画面：7/10。本作的画面是3D卡通风格，而且色彩相当绚烂。我个人不太喜欢这种风格的3D（但是很喜欢2D），饱和度太高看上去有点伤眼，而且画面太花不方便扫图；但是作为老游戏分辨率还不错，人物建模虽然糙了点不过也能接受， 总体来说还可以。

音乐和配音：7/10。不知道为什么，这游戏的音乐和画面都有点像《The Whispered World》，可能是这俩家都是德国的工作室，而且本作的场景设计也是TWW美术的原因吧。音乐还好，配音稍微有点生硬，感觉还是德语好一些。

剧情：6.5/10。本作的剧情属于又老套又短的那种：一个巨魔教授发现了一个有力量的神器，结果被邪恶一方绑架。教授让救他的精灵妹子Ivo去找神器，让矮人小哥Wilbur去给人类大法师传话；这两人后来遇到之后一起去找神器，在路上又结识了宝藏猎人Nate和他的宠物Critter。游戏一共5章，前面这段就是前两章的内容……流程大约6-8小时，整体来说虽然有4个主角但是明显戏份不一样，而且有很多设定还有很大的展开空间，所以只能说是及格水平。不过剧情有意思的一点是里面充满了各种幽默段子，虽然讽刺不够辛辣但是尺度还可以，是个老少皆宜的幽默故事。

操作和解谜：8/10。首先说一下，本作用空格可以显示Hotspot……这游戏扫图也是相当恶心，没这个功能会卡关卡很久。这游戏解谜最大的创新就是多人联动：不同角色有不同的特点，随着剧情的推进可操控角色的组合也会变化，需要根据周围环境切换角色通关；第三章的3人合作是我最喜欢的谜题，设计的太好了。除此之外，游戏在剧情与解谜结合的部分也做的不错，整体难度也还可以（略低于Deponia），小游戏也很有创意（虽然跳舞机那里我挂了好几次hhh），除了前面谜题太单调之外没什么缺点。

总的来说，《未传之书》是个剧情很有趣，但解谜比剧情有意思的游戏，不过本作没卡没成就，只适合对文字AVG有爱的玩家。

最后，攻略请戳下方指南：
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=465627259

15846169.review:
Well, what's there to say. It's a point&click adventure alright, but it's genuinely fun, fully voice acted, has very few stupid minigames and a reasonably pretty world.

You get to meet interesting characters, and the game makes fun about a lot of stuff you find in fantasy-themed games without being ridiculous or stupid (in fact, they even named the old gremlin who set all of this in motion "MacGuffin"). Expect some real laughs from it.

The puzzles are not overly complex, although I seemed to have missed a detail occasionally so I kept wandering around until I noticed. Never asked daddy Google, though.

Occasionally it drags on a bit since retrying stuff often involves going through some cutscene-ish scenes as well, or simply because you don't exactly know what to do next and walking through places just takes time. The rest of the game more than makes up for that, though.

You also get to play a total of 4 characters, usually on their own, but sometimes you get several of them in a scene and you can (and have to) switch between them. Switching takes a bit of time too, as they walk to some neutral position before actually switching, but you get used to it. It's not like you have to perform time critical action feats.
Of course, all of these (and the non-player characters as well) come with their own personality.

In general, I'm not a point&click expert, but I can definitely recommend this. In my opinion, a few minor shortcomings pale in comparison to the characters, story telling and humor -- and puzzles that don't feel contrived.
